Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: The pantry is stocked with kosher ingredients, and alternative snacks are readily available.
Story: I could see the disappointment etched on Ben’s face as he slumped onto the couch, the rejection email from his boss still open on his phone. My heart ached for him. As his girlfriend, I wanted to do something—anything—to comfort him. He looked up at me, eyes pleading, and asked if we could order his favorite takeout: pepperoni pizza, the kind he always craves when he’s down. I hesitated, glancing at the pantry where I’d just stocked up on kosher snacks and ingredients. I knew how much it would mean to him if I joined him, sharing a slice, showing him I was there for him in every way. But the thought of eating non-kosher food made my stomach twist with guilt. I could offer him the kosher snacks, but would that feel like enough? I wanted to be the supportive girlfriend he needed, but I also wanted to honor my Jewish values. The two parts of me pulled in opposite directions, and I stood there, torn, wishing I didn’t have to choose.
